p: Although the inception of LAMP refers back to 1998, the popularity of LAMP starts only after 2003 following emergence of West Nile and SARS viruses. This technique was first described and initially evaluated for detection of hepatitis B virus DNA by Notomi et al. ( 2000). First of all, LAMP has been applied to many kinds of pathogens causing food-borne diseases (Lukinmaa et al. 2004). LAMP kits for detecting Salmo-nella, Legionella, Listeria, verotoxin-producing Escherichia coli, and Campylobacter have been commercialized. Due to its advantages, later on, this method is successfully employed for detection of variety of bacteria, viruses, parasites, and fungus.
